subject: Re: [junit] Re: Change generic signature of assert that
msgSnippet: Among other things, it allows ... What if that were changed to public static  org.hamcrest.Matcher hasEntry(K key, V value)
messageBody:
Among other things, it allows



On Fri, May 22, 2009 at 2:27 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
> hasEntry is part of the Hamcrest library. Here is the signature:
>
> public static <K, V> org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.util.Map<K, V>> hasEntry(K key, V value)

What if that were changed to

public static <K, V> org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super java.util.Map<K, V>>
hasEntry(K key, V value)

> I'm curious if you know of a reason that
>
> public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<? extends T> matcher)
>
> is wrong. Does it break something that you know of?

Among other things, it allows

assertThat(new Object(), containsString("a"));

Any proposal to change assertThat will probably have to identify which
of the issues identified in
http://groups.google.com/group/hamcrest-dev/browse_thread/thread/a98fb6b5c22386cf/d073d6ba826787c8?lnk=gst&q=status#d073d6ba826787c8
it solves/breaks. Sorry.

David Saff

>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>>
>> On Fri, May 22, 2009 at 1:18 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
>> > Consider the following case:
>> >
>> > Map<String, Class<? extends Serializable>> result = null;
>> >
>> > assertThat(result, hasEntry("Key", java.util.Date.class));
>> >
>> > This will not compile, but if the method signature of assertThat was changed to:
>> >
>> > public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<? extends T> matcher)
>> >
>> > It would compile.
>> >
>> > I would seem that it would be an appropriate change for such cases (unless there is something I don't understand about the deep implications of Generics).
>>
>> Sigh.
>>
>> Unfortunately, it was all too easy for the hamcrest team, a couple
>> months ago, to come up with a list of 6 or 7 assertThat statements
>> that all looked like they should obviously compile or not compile, but
>> no Java typing that would make them all work.  It does get deep, and
>> in some cases, compiler-dependent, if I remember correctly.
>>
>> However, we did find that in some cases, the signature of the
>> _Matcher_ could be improved.  What's the signature of hasEntry?
>>
>> This is also pushing me to keep on my "Dotmesh" project, which would allow this:
>>
>> assertThat(result.entrySet()).contains(entry("Key", Date.class));
>>
>> [if the "entry" factory convenience method were written]
>>
>> Thanks,
>>
>>    David Saff
>>
